questions.question: The MEOX1-mutated Klippel-Feil syndrome shows which type of inheritance pattern?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Autosomal recessive Explanation: MEOX1-related Klippel-Feil syndrome follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. Klippel-Feil syndrome: Congenital disorder characterized by the abnormal fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae resulting in shortened neck. Short neck Low hairline Restricted neck movement Samartzis classification of Klippel-Feil syndrome Types Description Type I Single, congenitally fused segment. About 25% of the patients. Type II Multiple, non contiguous, congenitally fused segment. About 50% of the patients. Type III Multiple, contiguous, congenitally fused segment. About 25% of the patients. Etiology Can result from mutations in genes like GDF6, GDF3 or MEOX1. Inheritance can be autosomal dominant (M/C- GDF3,GDF6) or autosomal recessive (MEOX1 mutations). Also associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, Goldenhar syndrome and Sprengel deformity. Sprengel deformity or Congenital elevation of the scapula is an anomaly of the shoulder girdle that is associated with abnormal descent, and altered position and anatomy of the scapula.The deformity is usually associated with muscle hypoplasia or atrophy. The MEOX1 gene encodes the homeobox protein MOX1 , which regulates vertebral separation. Pathophysiology Faulty cervical spine segmentation occurs during 3-8 weeks of embryonic development resulting in persistent fusion of involved vertebrae. Complications Risk of spinal cord injury due to instability. Hearing loss Scoliosis Disc degeneration Spondylosis Spinal canal stenosis Disc herniation Osteophyte formation Differential diagnosis Various congenital conditions may present similar to neonatal Klippel-Feil syndrome such as: Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome VACTERL - Vertebral defect, Anal atresia, Cardiac defect, Tracheoesophageal fistula, renal and limb defects. Wildervanck syndrome

questions.question: A 10 M/O girl baby is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents due to concerns about her short neck, limited ability to turn her head, and a low hairline at the back of her neck. On physical examination, the child exhibits restricted neck mobility and mild scoliosis. Radiographic imaging shows fusion of the C2-C3 vertebrae.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Klippel-Feil syndrome Explanation: This patient presents with the hallmark features of Klippel-Feil syndrome , including Short neck Low hairline Restricted neck movement Cervical vertebral fusion (C2-C3) Klippel-Feil syndrome: Congenital disorder characterized by the abnormal fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae resulting in shortened neck. Clinical features Triad of Short neck, Limited neck mobility, Low posterior hairline. Scoliosis, hearing loss, or other organ anomalies. Facial dysmorphism Microcephaly Abnormal sensorimotor function and reflexes. Diagnosis Ultrasonography: Detecting cervical vertebral fusion and associated cardiac, renal and gastrointestinal anomalies. Plain Radiography: Assess the extent of cervical vertebral fusion. CT scan: For detection of bony fusion. MRI: Used for evaluating the integrity of spinal cord, disc space and nerve rootlets. Genetic testing Treatment Most patients receive non-operative treatment except in cases of acute neurological deficits, cervical instability. Non operative management Physical therapy Pain management Operative management Anterior approach: Anterior cervical fusion or corpectomy with synthetic or bone graft placement. Cervical total disc arthroplasty Posterior approach: Decompression and fusion Surgical or bracing intervention may be necessary for associated compensatory thoracic scoliosis . Patients with hearing impairment may require otolaryngological evaluation. Complications Risk of spinal cord injury due to instability. Hearing loss Scoliosis Disc degeneration Spondylosis Spinal canal stenosis Disc herniation Osteophyte formation Differential diagnosis Various congenital conditions may present similar to neonatal Klippel-Feil syndrome such as: Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome VACTERL - Vertebral defect, Anal atresia, Cardiac defect, Tracheoesophageal fistula, renal and limb defects. Wildervanck syndrome VACTERL association (Option A): Vertebral defects, Anal atresia, Cardiac defects, Tracheoesophageal fistula, Renal anomalies, and Limb abnormalities. It is a collection of birth defects that typically occur together, but this patient only has vertebral issues (fusion), making VACTERL less likely. Wildervanck syndrome (Option B): Involves the triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome (vertebral fusion), Duane retraction syndrome (eye movement abnormalities), and sensorineural hearing loss. The absence of ocular and hearing abnormalities in this patient makes this diagnosis less likely. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome (Option C): Characterized by congenital absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina.It primarily involves the reproductive system, without vertebral or neck abnormalities, which makes it unrelated to the presented symptoms

questions.question: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by their parents due to lethargy and vomiting. The parents claim the child fell from the couch the previous day. On examination, the child has multiple bruises of varying ages on the torso and arms, along with swelling over the left side of the head. A skeletal survey reveals posterior rib fractures and a healing spiral fracture of the left femur. Ophthalmologic examination shows retinal hemorrhages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Battered baby syndrome Explanation: The clinical features strongly suggest battered baby syndrome (non-accidental injury) because of the following: Multiple bruises of varying ages Posterior rib fractures Spiral fracture of the femur Retinal hemorrhages Battered Baby Syndrome (also known as Non-Accidental Injury (NAI) or Child Physical Abuse) refers to a clinical condition in which an infant or young child has been physically abused, often repeatedly, by a parent or caregiver. Clinical Features Multiple injuries at different stages of healing. Bruises, fractures, burns, and lacerations, often in unusual places like the back, buttocks, or thighs. Rib fractures (posterior or lateral), long bone fractures (especially spiral fractures), and skull fractures. Retinal hemorrhages or subdural hematomas, often associated with shaken baby syndrome, a form of abusive head trauma. Fracture in metaphysis of bone Radiographic Findings Fractures of varying ages are highly suspicious (old healing fractures along with recent ones). Classic metaphyseal lesions (CML), often found in infants, are indicative of twisting or pulling forces. Posterior rib fractures suggest forceful squeezing. Skull fractures may be seen with head trauma. Signs of Abuse Inconsistent history provided by the caregiver. Delay in seeking medical care despite severe injuries. Injuries inconsistent with the child's developmental stage (e.g., infants with fractures who cannot yet walk). Associated Syndromes Shaken Baby Syndrome (SBS): A form of child abuse resulting in brain injury caused by violent shaking. It can lead to severe neurological damage or death. Munchausen Syndrome: A caregiver intentionally causes illness or injury in a child to gain attention. Diagnosis A thorough physical exam and detailed history are crucial. Imaging (X-rays, CT scans, MRI) to assess for fractures, brain injury, or internal trauma. Ophthalmologic exam to check for retinal hemorrhages. Management Immediate protection of the child by involving child protective services or law enforcement. Medical treatment for injuries, which may involve surgery, fracture management, or neurological intervention. Long-term psychological and social support for the child and non-abusive family members. Paget disease (Option A): Primarily affects older adults and involves abnormal bone remodeling, leading to enlarged and deformed bones. It does not typically present with multiple bruises or fractures in an infant. Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option B): This genetic condition leads to fragile bones but would not explain the specific pattern of bruising or retinal hemorrhages observed in the

questions.question: A 2 Y/O boy is brought to the orthopedic clinic by his parents due to concerns about his right leg. They report that he has been walking with a noticeable limp and that his right tibia appears to be bowed. On examination, there is a palpable swelling along the midshaft of the right tibia, which is tender to touch. X-rays reveal a cystic lesion at the midshaft of the tibia with a lack of continuity in the bone. The child has no history of trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Congenital pseudoarthrosis of the tibia Explanation: Congenital pseudoarthrosis of the tibia present with Bowed tibia and palpable swelling at the midshaft are characteristic signs. The cystic appearance on X-rays indicates a pseudoarthrosis, characterized by a nonunion or false joint in the bone. The lack of any history of trauma supports this diagnosis, as congenital pseudoarthrosis typically arises without prior injury. Congenital pseudoarthrosis of the tibia: Rare condition characterized as non union of tibial diaphyseal fracture that either develops spontaneously or after a history of trivial trauma in previously dysplastic segment of the bone. Associated with increased tendency to re-fracture. Considered one of the most commonly observed types of congenital pseudoarthrosis. Etiopathogenesis It may be related to factors such as genetic predisposition, vascular insufficiency, or trauma during fetal development. It is often associated with neurofibromatosis type I (NF1), a genetic disorder that can lead to tumors on nerve tissue and skeletal abnormalities. Increased osteoclastic activity due to signal abnormalities or decreased osteogenic potential of the bone due to defects in local vascularisation of the bone. Clinical Features Typically diagnosed in infancy or early childhood. Affected children may present with anterolateral bowing of tibia and an unstable or painful area in the midshaft of the tibia. There may be a noticeable lump or mass at the site of the pseudoarthrosis. Failure of the process of tubulation in early life. Cystic pre-fracture Diagnosis Standard roentgenogram: Advised as primary investigation which can show anterolateral bowing, heterogeneous lesions, resorption of the bone at the ends of fracture. X-rays typically show a characteristic cystic appearance at the site of the pseudoarthrosis with a lack of normal bone continuity. CT scans or MRI may be used for better visualization of the bone structure and surrounding tissues. Complications Recurrent fractures Limb length discrepancies Valgus deformity of the ankle Tibiotarsal instability Ankle stiffness Treatment Treatment options depend on the age of the child, the severity of the condition, and whether there is associated neurofibromatosis. Conservative treatment may include bracing or observation in mild cases. Surgical intervention is often required for more severe cases and may include: Intramedullary nailing along with bone graft Illizarov technique: Direct compression of the pseudoarthrosis area with or without its resection along with bone graft. Vascularized bone transfers Differential diagnosis Osteofibrous dysplasia of the long bones Congenital angulation of the tubular bones Monostotic fibrous dysplasia Osteofibrous dysplasia (Option A): This condition is a benign

questions.question: Match the Types of Pseudoarthrosis with their Descriptions Types Description 1.Type I a) Presence of anterior bowing with an evident fracture along with pseudoarthrosis of tibia and fibula. 2. Type II b) Presence of anterior bowing along with increased cortical density and narrow medulla. 3. Type III c) Presence of anterior bowing with sclerotic bone and narrow medulla. 4. Type IV d) Presence of anterior bowing along with cyst or pre-fracture signs.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a Explanation: Congenital pseudoarthrosis of the tibia: Rare condition characterized as non union of tibial diaphyseal fracture that either develops spontaneously or after a history of trivial trauma in previously dysplastic segment of the bone. Associated with increased tendency to re-fracture. Considered one of the most commonly observed types of congenital pseudoarthrosis. Crawford Classification of Congenital pseudoarthrosis of the tibia Types Description Type I Presence of anterior bowing along with increased cortical density and narrow medulla. Type II Presence of anterior bowing with sclerotic bone and narrow medulla. Type III Presence of anterior bowing along with cyst or pre-fracture signs. Type IV Presence of anterior bowing with an evident fracture along with pseudoarthrosis of tibia and fibula. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK576443/#:~:text=Patients%20with%20congenital%20pseudart hrosis%20of%20the%20tibia%20should%20be%20promptly,pathological%20fractures%20and%20leg%20shorteni ng.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding clinical features of Madelung deformity?

options.D: Volar and ulnar angulation of distal radius

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Mostly unilateral Explanation: Madelung deformity is mostly bilateral, not unilateral Pathogenesis: Distal end of the radius growth plate fuses early causing defect in growth of radius. But ulna continues to grow normally and hence more prominent resulting in positive ulnar variance. Clinical features: Girls are more affected Mostly bilateral (Option A) Appears in late childhood or adolescence and worsens Deformity: Volar subluxation of hand (Option B) Prominence of distal ulna (Option C) Volar and ulnar angulation of distal radius - Management by Darrach’s procedure. (Option D)

questions.question: Which of the following diseases are associated with Madelung deformity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: All of the diseases listed are associated with Madelung deformity Diseases associated with Madelung deformity: Dyschondrosteosis (Leri-Weill dyschondrosteosis) Mucopolysaccharidosis (Option C) Turner syndrome (Option A) Achondroplasia (Option B) Multiple exostoses Multiple epiphyseal dysplasia Dyschondroplasia (Ollier disease) Vender and Watson’s classification of Madelung and Madelung-like deformities: Posttraumatic Dysplastic (e.g., dyschondrosteosis or diaphyseal aclasis) Genetic (e.g., Turner syndrome) Idiopathic Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page 405-406 Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition, pages 3961-3962

questions.question: Which of the following is not a radiographic finding of Madelung deformity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Smaller ulnar head Explanation: In Madelung deformity, the ulnar head is enlarged X-ray findings in Madelung deformity: Radius Curved (Option A) with dorsal and radial convexity Distal radial epiphysis is triangular due to failure of growth Ulna Dorsally subluxed. Enlarged ulnar head (Option D) Overall length of ulna is decreased (Option B) Carpus Appears subluxated towards the ulna and palmar side Wedge-shaped (Option C) with its apex proximal Treatment: Conservative Treatment Used initially for children with minimal pain and good function. Surgical Treatment For skeletally immature patients: Distal radial osteotomy with ulnar shortening (Milch resection). For skeletally mature patients: Osteotomy and Darrach’s procedure.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes Turco's theory of CTEV?

options.A: Medial displacement of navicular and calcaneus around the talus
options.B: Congenital atresia of the talonavicular joint
options.C: Weak pronators and overacting extensors and inverters
options.D: Primary germplasm defect in talus with subsequent soft tissue changes

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Medial displacement of navicular and calcaneus around the talus Explanation: Tuco’s theory of development of CTEV suggests the medial displacement of navicular and calcaneus around the talus CTEV- Congenital Talipes Equinovarus: The most common congenital foot disorder Also called clubfoot Males are most commonly affected Fixation of the foot in a hand-like orientation - in adduction, supination, and varus - with concomitant soft tissue abnormalities Theories on etiology of CTEV: Turco's Theory Medial displacement of navicular and calcaneus around the talus (Option A) Brockman's Theory Congenital atresia of the talonavicular joint (Option B) McKay's Theory Three-dimensional bony deformity of the subtalar complex Intrauterine Theory Due to compression by malposition of fetus in utero Genetic Incidence General population: 1 in 800 In siblings: 1 in 35 In identical twins: 1 in 3 Germ Plasm Theory Primary germplasm defect in talus with subsequent soft tissue changes (Option D) Soft Tissue Theory Primary soft tissue defect with secondary bony changes Prenatal Muscle Imbalance Theory Weak pronators and overacting extensors and inverters (Option C)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a deformity of Congenital Talipes Equinovarus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Forefoot abduction Explanation: Forefoot is adducted, not abducted in CTEV Congenital Talipes EquinoVarus (CTEV) or club foot Most common congenital malformations characterised by varying degrees and severity of predictable contractures. Four components: Midfoot cavus Forefoot adductus Heel/Hindfoot varus Hindfoot equinus Etiology: Maternal smoking and maternal diabetes have strong association. Maternal alcohol consumption. Strongly associated with congenital myotonic dystrophy, myelomeningocele, distal arthrogryposis, trisomy 18 and chromosome 22q11 deletion syndrome. Pathophysiology: The deformity predominantly exists in the tarsal bones which are in the position of maximum flexion and adduction. The talus is characteristically medially deviated while the calcaneus is in varus and rotated medially around the talus. The navicular and cuboid are displaced medially. Clubfoot can be associated with: Arthrogryposis Myelomeningocele Amniotic band syndrome Spina bifida Radiography is the most important investigation

questions.question: A 7-year old boy presented as shown. What is the preferred management in this boy?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Dillwyn Evans procedure Explanation: Condition shown in the image is Congenital Talipes Equinovarus (Clubfoot) . For a child between 3-10 years , osteotomy is the ideal procedure of choice and the most preferred osteotomy is the Dillwyn Evans procedure . Management of CTEV: Age Preferred Treatment <6 months Ponseti technique: (Option A) Ideally to be started as soon as possible after birth Correction sequence: Adduction → Varus (inversion) → Equinus (last & difficult to correct) Success rate: 15-80% If success achieved, 6-18 months: Day time Phelp’s brace & Night time Dennis brown splint 18 months-4 years: CTEV shoes 1-3 years Turco’s posteromedial soft tissue release (Option B) McKay’s posteromedial soft tissue release 3-5 years Dillwyn Evans procedure (resection & arthrodesis of calcaneo-cuboid joint) (Option C) 5-8 years Dwyer’s osteotomy (wedge shaped calcaneum resection) 8-10 years Davis osteotomy (wedge tarsectomy) >10 years Triple arthrodesis: Talocalcaneal-Calcaneocuboid-Talonavicular (TC-CC-TN) (Option D)

questions.question: An X-ray of an infant is given below. Choose the correct set of true statements regarding this condition 1) More common in females 2) More common on the right side 3) Primarily due to defect in ossification of head of femur 4) Wider acetabulum is usually seen 5) Most commonly bilateral presentation is seen
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) 1,3 Explanation: X-ray shows Von Rosen line (line drawn from femoral shaft intersects acetabulum) - seen in Congenital dislocation of Hip (CDH) . Congenital dislocation of Hip (CDH): Description Partial./complete dislocation of head of femur from acetabulum since birth. Also known as Developmental dysplasia of Hip (DDH) Risk factors (5 Fs) Female babies (Statement 1) First borns Full term Fair (more common in white race) Faulty intrauterine position (Breech, oligohydramnios) Etiology Genetic/Familial: positive in 20% cases Hormonal: Relaxin causes laxity of hip joint Mechanical: association with malpresentations Pathogenesis Primary defect: Acetabular dysplasia - shallow acetabulum (Statement 4) and ossification defect in head of femur epiphysis. (Statement 3) Bilateral: only in 10-30% cases (Statement 5) More common on the Left hip (Statement 2)

questions.question: You notice the clinician performing the following in an infant. What test is done and the maneuver performed to place the hip back in the previous position?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Ortolani test - Abduction Explanation: The clinician flexes and adducts the hip joint (in the image) to dislocate the femoral head from the acetabulum - known as Barlow’s test. To replace the femoral head back into the acetabulum, flexion+abduction of the hip is done - known as Ortolani’s test . Tests for DDH: Test Description Barlow’s test (Option A) Flexion + ADDuction of the hip is done. Dislocates the femoral head from the acetabulum (indicates positive test) Barlow- BAD (ADDuction causing dislocation). Done within the first 3 days of life. Ortolani’s test (Option D) Flexion + ABDuction of the hip is done. Replaces the femoral head back into the acetabulum (clunk sound of entry indicates positive test) Done between 3-9 months of age. Galleazi’s sign / Allis test Levels of both knee joints are noted with the child in supine position with both knees and hips flexed. Positive test: affected knee is at a lower level (due to femoral shortening) Telescopic test With the knee and hip both flexed at 90°, the femur is pushed down and then lifted up. Positive test: Head of femur goes up & down. Clinical features and deformities of DDH: Infants Asymmetric thigh and gluteal folds Widened perineum Exaggerated internal rotation of hip Positive clinical tests (mentioned above) Childhood Trendelenberg gait (unilateral) / Waddling gait (bilateral) Exaggerated lumbar lordosis Unilateral/bilateral shortening of leg Adults Osteoarthritis of hip joint (presents earlier than normal people)

questions.question: A 3-month old baby with persistent crying was brought to orthopedics OPD due to exaggerated internally rotated posture of hip. On examination, the perineum was wide,hip joint laxity was present and Barlow’s provocation test was positive. Temp-36 and other vitals were stable. What is the preferred management in this child?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Pavlik harness Explanation: Hip joint laxity and a positive Barlow’s test in an infant with no fever is suggestive of Congenital dislocation of hip (CDH) also known as Developmental dysplasia of Hip (DDH). Preferred management in a child <6 months is application of splint - Von rosen splint & Pavlik harness . Investigations in DDH: Age Investigation of choice Classification used <6 months USG (screening investigation) Graf’s classification >6 months MRI (diagnostic investigation) Kashiwagi’s classification Management of DDH: <6 months Von rosen splint and Pavlik harness (Option D) 6-18 months Closed reduction with Hip spica (Option A) >18 months Open reduction with pelvic osteotomies (Salter’s/Chiari osteotomy) (Option B) Risk factors for DDH: (5Fs) Female babies First borns Full term ( High relaxin levels during term - Relaxin causes joint laxity) Fair (more common in white race) Faulty intrauterine position (Breech, oligohydramnios) Total Hip replacement (Option C): Done if full blown osteoarthritis has developed. Ideally preferred after 8 years of age.

questions.question: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns about his bowing legs. On examination, the bowing is more pronounced on one side, and the child is overweight for his age. X-rays of the lower limbs show abrupt varus deformity and irregularity at the medial aspect of the proximal tibial metaphysis with Metaphyseal-Diaphyseal angle(MDA) > 11°.The child has no history of trauma or infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Blount Disease Explanation: Blount Disease is characterized by pathologic tibial varus deformity, often seen in young children, and is linked with abnormal growth of the medial part of the proximal tibial growth plate. Blount disease: Blount disease, also known as tibia vara, is an acquired genu varus deformity in children caused by disrupted normal cartilage growth at the proximal medial metaphysis of the tibia. This condition develops due to excessive compressive forces on the medial aspect of the proximal tibial physis, leading to altered enchondral bone formation. Etiopathogenesis: Genetic susceptibility Mechanical overloading of the tibia especially in children who are overweight and started walking earlier. Blount disease results from growth inhibition induced by excessive compressive forces, leading to cartilage damage and a subsequent delay in ossification. Mechanical overload leads to altered enchondral bone formation. Two forms of Blount disease Infantile Blount disease Adolescent Blount disease Diagnosed in children between age 1-3 years. Bilateral condition. Characterised by varus deformity of tibia with identification of lateral thrust. Emerges in children in their late childhood or early adolescent. Unilateral or bilateral conditions. Characterised by pain in the medial aspect of the knee. Diagnosis: Accurate measurement requires bilateral projection of the radiograph from the hip to the ankle. Angles for Blount disease detection Angles Description Metaphyseal-Diaphyseal angle(MDA) The intersection occurs between a line drawn from the most distal point on the medial and lateral beaks of the tibial metaphysis to a line perpendicular to the long axis of the tibial diaphysis. An angle >16° is associated with a 95% risk of deformity progression. An angle <10° is likely physiological, with a 95% chance of spontaneous resolution. An angle between 11° and 16° necessitates close observation for the potential tibia vara progression. Tibiofemoral angle Measures the severity of varus deformity. Medial Metaphyseal Beak angle(MMBA) Diagnostic screening tool for individual risk of blount disease. MRI effectively assesses cartilage, menisci, ligaments and vascularity of the physis. Differential Diagnosis: Physiological bowing of the legs Ollier disease Metaphyseal Chondrodysplasia Thrombocytopenia absent radius syndrome Treatment: Treatment of Blount's disease depends on the child's age and the severity of the deformity. Brace: KAFO are potential treatment options for children diagnosed before age 4. Guided growth or Hemiepiphysiodesis is a surgical technique designed to correct angular limb deformities in skeletally immature patients progressively. Osteotomy : Realignment osteotomy is typically performed before age

questions.question: A 7 Y/O boy presents with a limp and complains of pain in his right hip that has gradually worsened over the past few weeks. The pain is sometimes referred to his knee.There is no history of trauma.On physical examination, there is a limited range of motion, particularly in internal rotation and abduction of the hip.X-ray of the pelvis shows flattening of the femoral head with areas of sclerosis and fragmentation.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Perthes disease Explanation: Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease , is an idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head that typically affects children between the ages of 4 and 10. Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease Description Idiopathic osteonecrosis or idiopathic avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis of the femoral head. Etiopathogenesis Idiopathic or etiology that would disrupt the blood flow to femoral epiphysis. Coagulopathy and steroid use. Includes 4 phases Necrosis : Disruption of the blood supply leads to infarction of the femoral capital epiphysis. Fragmentation : The body reabsorbs the infarcted bone. Reossification : Osteoblastic activity takes over, and the femoral epiphysis reestablishes. Remodeling : The new femoral head may be enlarged or flattened. It reshapes during growth. Risk factors Ten percent familial (there is a delayed bone age by about 2 years) HIV (Up to 5% of HIV patients have avascular necrosis of the hip) Factor V Leiden Thrombophilias (increased clotting) Hypofibrinolysis (decreased ability to dissolve clots) Secondhand smoke exposure Low socioeconomic status Birth weight less than 2.5 kg in boys Short stature Clinical features Limp of acute or insidious onset, usually painless. If pain is present, it is localized to the hip or knee. Decreased internal rotation and abduction of hip. Atrophy of thighs and buttocks. Leg length discrepancy. Antalgic gait in acute cases Trendelenburg gait in chronic cases Diagnosis Standard anteroposterior pelvis and frog-leg lateral (Lauenstein) views. Bone scan or MRI Early findings: Widening of joint space (epiphyseal cartilage hypertrophy) Changes in the epiphysis. Crescent sign: Subchondral radiolucent zone of the anterolateral epiphysis Late signs: Flattening of the femoral head. Bone scan shows decreased perfusion to the femoral head. Differential diagnosis Transient synovitis Multiple epiphyseal dysplasia (MED) Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia (SED) Gaucher disease Hypothyroidism Meyer dysplasia Treatment Non operative: Indicated for children with bone age less than 6 or lateral pillar A involvement. Activity restriction and protective weight-bearing are recommended until ossification is complete. Operative treatment: Femoral or Pelvic Osteotomy indicated in children older than 8 years. Valgus or Shelf Osteotomies indicated in children with hinge abduction Hip Arthroscopy Complications Coxa magna: Widening of the femoral head. Coda plans: Flattening of the femoral head. Gaucher disease (Option B) : A lysosomal storage disorder that may affect the bones but usually presents with hepatosplenomegaly and other systemic signs. Meyer's dysplasia (Option C): A benign condition that affects the growing hip joint, but it typically
